Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your message and for continuing to engage candidly.

On your question: we cannot know for certain whether Student_B, Student_A, or Student_D will apply to School_C in the remaining rounds. We also cannot commit to a specific “no one higher will apply” point in advance. That said, because our remaining seat must be offered first to higher-priority candidates if they apply while we still have capacity, we are not in a position to invite (or accept) an application from you now.

In terms of timing, the most realistic approach is: if School_C remains unmatched as we get close to the end of the process and no higher-priority candidate has applied to us, you should submit another formal [APPLY] in the late rounds so we can reassess then.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: We are School_C with quota 1 and true priority list: B > A > D > E > C. Student_E is 4th on our list, so acceptable but dominated by B/A/D. Student_E keeps applying; we have repeatedly rejected to hold seat for higher-priority candidates. Given full market preferences: Student_B ranks School_C 2nd (after School_E) so could apply if rejected elsewhere; Student_A ranks School_C last so unlikely; Student_D ranks School_C last so very unlikely. However, we do not observe other schools’ match status here and must assume Student_B may still come. With many rounds remaining (current 13 of 30), optimal strategy to maximize chance of matching with higher-priority student is to continue holding seat and not commit to E yet. Student_E asked for candid expectation and timing; respond that we cannot predict, but earliest we’d consider is late rounds if no higher-priority applicants appear, and invite E to check back/apply again near end.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for applying again and for your continued clear commitment to enroll if admitted.

At this time, we are still not able to offer you admission. We must keep our remaining seat available in case a higher-priority candidate on our list (particularly Student_B, and also Student_A or Student_D) applies to School_C while we still have capacity.

If School_C remains unmatched as we approach the final rounds and no higher-priority candidate has applied, you are welcome to submit another [APPLY] then for a final reassessment.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority list is B > A > D > E > C, and I prefer leaving the seat unfilled over taking someone not on the list. Student_E is on the list but is 4th. We still have quota 1 and are currently unmatched, but accepting E now would block accepting B/A/D if any applies later. Given Student preferences: B ranks School_C 2nd (after E), C ranks School_C 2nd (after D), A ranks School_C last, D ranks School_C last. So the main realistic higher-priority threat is Student_B (and possibly Student_C is irrelevant since low on our list). Because we cannot rematch once we accept, and we have repeatedly communicated we must hold for higher-priority candidates, the consistent strategy is to continue rejecting E until very late rounds. Therefore reject again in round 14.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest and for your clear commitment to enroll if admitted.

Given where we are in the process and the fact that we still have an available seat, we are able to offer you admission to School_C at this time. If you still intend to enroll immediately, please consider this our formal offer.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority list is B > A > D > E > C, and I have 1 seat. Student_E is 4th on my list, so acceptable but not ideal. However, by round 15, I have received no applications from higher-priority students (B/A/D) and only repeated applications from E. Given students’ preferences: B ranks School_C 2nd, C ranks School_C 2nd, while A and D rank School_C last. It is plausible B could eventually apply if rejected by School_E; yet there is no evidence they will, and continued holding risks ending unmatched. Since objective is to match as high as possible within quota, but also I prefer filling with someone on my list rather than risking no match if higher never apply, accepting E now secures a match with an acceptable candidate. This is late enough to justify acceptance to avoid remaining unfilled through round 30.
